Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Small: Improving Data Center Water Efficiency via Online Resource Management

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
A large data center may consume millions of gallons of cooling water each day; in addition, data centers also indirectly consume an enormous amount of water embedded in offsite electricity generation. As a result, water conservation is surfacing as a critical concern for data centers, amid the anticipation of surging water demand worldwide. Left unchecked, the growing water footprint of data centers can pose a severe threat to data center sustainability and may even handicap availability of services, especially for data centers in water-stressed areas. Existing mechanical solutions for conservation, such as using recycled/industry water and directly using outside cold air, are often costly and/or very limited by external factors such as locations, climate conditions, among others.

As part of the integral efforts from both industry and academy to enable data center sustainability, this project uniquely integrates water footprint as an essential part of resource management in virtualized data centers. It exploits the inherent yet little-known characteristics of time-varying water efficiency and optimizes resource management for minimizing operational cost as well as water footprint without compromising service quality. To this end, this project investigates three complementary research thrusts: (i) Online computing resource management for water sustainability in the presence of large unknown dynamics (such as highly volatile outside temperature); (ii) Exploration of the dependency of data center water efficiency on cooling systems, and joint optimization of cooling and computing resource management for water sustainability; (iii) Experimentation and validation based on combined system prototyping and software simulation. In addition to its environmental impacts, this project has large societal impacts for its potential to alleviate the growing pressure on data center water footprint effectively and economically. This project will enhance the understanding of interplay among water consumption, power/energy consumption, and resource management in data centers, and lay a solid foundation for sustainable evolvement of greener data centers. New findings and techniques will be readily incorporated into teaching materials. The project also contains a significant component to promote diversity by inspiring minority students, especially Hispanic students, to engage in computer science research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data centers are mission-critical infrastructures supporting our digital economy. Nonetheless, a data center can consume millions of gallons of water for cooling; it also indirectly consumes an enormous amount of water embedded in offsite electricity generation. Consequently, the growing water footprint has been quickly emerging as a critical concern for data centers, which poses a severe threat to data center sustainability and can even handicap availability of services in water-stressed regions. The existing mechanical solutions for water conservation, such as using recycled/industry water and directly using outside cold air, are often costly and/or significantly limited by external factors such as locations, climate conditions, among others. As part of the integral efforts from both industry and academy to enable data center sustainability, this project develops software-based resource management approaches to reduce data center water footprint without compromising service quality. Specifically, throughout this project, our research team has made the following important contributions.

First, we have identified two inherent yet little-known characteristics of data center water efficiency: spatial-temporal diversities. Concretely, as data centers are located in different regions with different and time-varying climate conditions, electricity fuel mixes and cooling methods, data center water efficiency exhibits spatial-temporal diversities, based on which incoming workloads can be dynamically routed to different data centers. We have also developed a quantitative model of data center water efficiency, which enables rigorous optimization of resource management for reducing water footprint in practical systems.

Second, we have developed a water-aware resource management approach to achieve water sustainability in geo-distributed data centers. Our approach, called WATCH (WATer-constrained workload sCHeduling in data centers), caps data centers’ long-term water consumption by exploiting spatio-temporal diversities of water efficiency and dynamically dispatching workloads among distributed data centers. We demonstrate the effectiveness of WATCH both analytically and empirically using experiments: based on only online information, WATCH can result in a provably-low operational cost while successfully capping water consumption under a desired level. Our results also show that WATCH can cut water consumption by 20% while only incurring a negligible cost increase even compared to state-of-the-art cost-minimizing but water-oblivious solution.

Third, we employ a holistic cyber-physical approach and incorporate water footprint into data center resource management to achieve an optimal tradeoff among water footprint, carbon emission, electricity cost, and workload performance. Specifically, our online batch job scheduling algorithm, called WACE (minimization of WAter, Carbon and Electricity cost), dynamically optimize geographic load balancing and server resource provisioning to minimize the water consumption along with carbon emission and electricity cost while satisfying average delay performance requirement. WACE can be implemented online without foreseeing the far future information and yields a total cost that is provably close to the optimal algorithm with look-ahead information. Our experiments demonstrate that, compared to state of the art, 25% water saving can be achieved while incurring an acceptable service delay increase.

Fourth, we have developed both experimental prototype and simulation platform to evaluate our theoretical results and compare them against state of the art. Our prototype includes multiple Dell PowerEdge servers that are virtualized to run real data center workloads, while our simulation platform is developed based on Matlab and Java to capture large-scale system designs.

Finally, throughout this project, total six Ph.D. students and three undergraduate students participated in the research activities. The research results of this project are part of the Ph.D. students’ dissertations, and have also been included into two graduate courses and one undergraduate course: Cyber Sustainability, Data Center Management (undergraduate level), and Data Center Architecture. Among the three undergraduate students, two were supported by the REU supplement of this project, and two were from underrepresented groups (Hispanic and African American). Based on research from this project, we have published more than 20 peer-reviewed journal/conference papers and 1 book chapter. We have disseminated the research of this project to communities of interest through more than 10 research seminars (at Caltech, UCLA, NCSU, etc.), 1 week-long short course at the summer school organized by the European Networkof Excellence HiPEAC, and 2 workshops. Moreover, our research helps increase the public awareness of water conservation in information technology industries, e.g., contributing to media reports on data center’s enormous water footprint published by Bloomberg, EARTH Magazine, Wall Street Journal, etc.
